messageBody:
On Wed, 2004-05-12 at 03:17, shockofpoint6@... wrote:
[snip]
> Any suggestions?
>
> Is my use of an __internalconstructor wrong? Is there another way to
> not duplicate constructor code, but to still let multiple constructors
> call the same functionality?

Some thoughts...

You can IntroduceFactoryMethod. One benefit here is that the factory
method can describe the instance you are creating much better than the
difference in parameters can describe it in a traditional ctor.

Another thing you could do is not test the __internalconstructor via
reflection, but make separate test cases for instances which reflect the
different construction mechanisms. You are thus indirectly testing the
private method. Testing privates vs. publics has been covered at length
on this list as well as other sources (Wikis, papers, boards, etc.).
You can Google for that type of discussion.

Eg. (not the best, but it should give you the idea):

class Surgery {
public static Surgery heartSurgeryForDiabeticPatient(Patient patient)
{
// special condition (Diabetes) exists as well as other conditions
common to heart surgery patients
...
}
public static Surgery heartSurgery(Patient patient) {
// no special restrictions other than those common to heart
surgeries
...
}
}

versus

class Surgery {
public Surgery(Patient patient) {
this(patient, diabetic(patient));
}
public Surgery(Patient patient, Complication complication) {
this(patient, complication);
}
}

--
